literal_meaning: There is no rose without thorns.
figurative_meaning: Every beautiful thing has its drawbacks.
example: Every job has its challenges; nie ma róży bez kolców.

figurative_meaning: To talk to someone who is not listening.
example: Trying to explain it to him is like mówić jak do ściany.

literal_meaning: To catch two magpies by the tail.
figurative_meaning: To try to achieve two goals at once.
example: By working on both projects simultaneously, he is trying to złapać dwie sroki za ogon.

idiom: Nie ma co płakać nad rozlanym mlekiem
literal_meaning: There’s no point crying over spilled milk.
figurative_meaning: Don’t waste time worrying about things that cannot be changed.
example: It’s done now; nie ma co płakać nad rozlanym mlekiem.

idiom: Gdzie dwóch się bije, tam trzeci korzysta
literal_meaning: Where two fight, a third benefits.
figurative_meaning: In conflicts, a third party often gains.
example: While they argue, someone else is taking advantage; gdzie dwóch się bije, tam trzeci korzysta.

literal_meaning: What does gingerbread have to do with a windmill.
figurative_meaning: What does this have to do with that?
example: When she brought up unrelated topics, I thought, co ma piernik do wiatraka?
If people are talking about it, there must be something; nie ma dymu bez ognia.

figurative_meaning: To give something valuable to those who won’t appreciate it.
example: Don’t waste your time explaining it to him; rzucać perły przed wieprze.

literal_meaning: As a dog with a cat.
example: They argue all the time; they live jak pies z kotem.
In this house, everything has swoje miejsce.
